0.description: Lets you define the border color for trend-arc.
0.name: borderColor
0.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

1.description: Color of the trend point. The color of the text can be configured using Styles
1.name: color
1.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

2.description: Length of each dash gap, if trend-point is plotted as dashed line.
2.name: dashGap
2.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

3.description: Length of each dash, if trend-point is plotted as dashed line.
3.name: dashLen
3.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

4.description: If you're showing the trend point as line, this attribute lets you control whether the line will be plotted as dashed?
4.name: dashed
4.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

5.description: Display label for the trend-point/trend-arc. If you do not specify a value, the chart displays the numeric value.
5.name: displayValue
5.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

6.description: The ending value for the trend-point. Say, if you want to plot a trend-arc from value 102 to 109, the `endValue` will be 109.
6.name: endValue
6.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

7.description: In case of trend-arc, radius for inner side of arc.
7.name: innerRadius
7.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

8.description: Border color of marker.
8.name: markerBorderColor
8.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

9.description: Fill color of marker.
9.name: markerColor
9.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

10.description: Radius of the marker.
10.name: markerRadius
10.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

11.description: You can define the tooltip for a marker using this attribute.
11.name: markerTooltext
11.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

12.description: Radius for trend point/outer side of trend-arc.
12.name: radius
12.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

13.description: If you're drawing a trend-arc, you can set its border on using this attribute.
13.name: showBorder
13.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

14.description: The starting value for the trend-point. Say, if you want to plot a trend-arc from value 102 to 109, the `startValue` will be 102.
14.name: startValue
14.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

15.description: If you've opted to show the trend as a point, this attribute lets you define the thickness of trend line.
15.name: thickness
15.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

16.description: You can opt to show a triangular marker for each trend-point by setting this attribute to 1.
16.name: useMarker
16.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

17.description: Whether to display the trend-point value inside the gauge?
17.name: valueInside
17.category: The trendPoint Object and the point Object

18.description: If you want to link the logo to an external URL, specify the link in this attribute. The link can be in FusionCharts link format, allowing you to link to new windows, pop-ups, frames etc.
18.name: logoLink

19.description: Height of minor tick marks.
19.name: minorTMHeight

20.description: Thickness of minor tick marks.
20.name: minorTMThickness

21.description: Distance between tick values and tick marks.
21.name: tickValueDistance

22.description: Distance between trend values and tick lines.
22.name: trendValueDistance

23.description: If you need to show every n-th tick value only, you can specify that value here.
23.name: tickValueStep

24.description: Number of decimals to which tick values will be rounded to.
24.name: tickValueDecimals

25.description: Whether to force number of decimals on tick values?
25.name: forceTickValueDecimals

26.description: Whether to ask the chart to automatically place tick values to reduce overlapping of the tick values with the gauge.
26.name: autoAlignTickValues

Sets whether the trend-line display value will be bold formatted.

Default value: 100

Default value: 100
7.name: trendValueBgAlpha

Sets the transparency for the border around the trend-line display value. 

Default value: 100
8.name: trendValueBorderAlpha

9.description: Sets padding for the border around the trend-line display value.

22.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers visible on the graph. For example, to represent all dollars figure on the chart, you could specify this attribute to $ to show like $40000, $50000. The value of this attribute works only if `yNumberPrefix` and `xNumberPrefix` attributes are not specifically mentioned.
22.name: numberPrefix

23.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers visible on the y-axis. For example, to represent all dollars figure on the y-axis, you could specify this attribute to $ to show like $40000, $50000. If this attribute is not specifically mentioned, the chart inherits the default value from `numberPrefix` attribute.
23.name: yNumberPrefix

24.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers visible on the x-axis. For example, to represent all dollars figure on the x-axis, you could specify this attribute to $ to show like $40000, $50000. If this attribute is not specifically mentioned, the chart inherits the default value from `numberPrefix` attribute.
24.name: xNumberPrefix

25.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the graph. For example, to represent all figures quantified as per annum on the chart, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a. The value of this attribute works only if `yNumberSuffix` and `xNumberSuffix` attributes are not specifically mentioned.
25.name: numberSuffix

26.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the y-axis. For example, to represent all figure quantified as per annum on the y-axis, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a. If this attribute is not specifically mentioned, the chart inherits the default value from `numberSuffix` attribute.
26.name: yNumberSuffix

27.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the x-axis. For example, to represent all figure quantified as per annum on the x-axis, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a.If this attribute is not specifically mentioned, the chart inherits the default value from `numberSuffix` attribute.
27.name: xNumberSuffix

28.description: This attribute helps you specify the character to be used as the decimal separator in a number.
28.name: decimalSeparator

29.description: This attribute helps you specify the character to be used as the thousands separator in a number.
29.name: thousandSeparator

30.description: This option helps you specify the position of the thousand separator.
30.name: thousandSeparatorPosition

31.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, FusionCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the decimal separator.
31.name: inDecimalSeparator

32.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, FusionCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the thousand separator.
32.name: inThousandSeparator

33.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers on the chart will be rounded to.
33.name: decimals

34.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all the numbers, set this attribute to 1.
34.name: forceDecimals

35.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
35.name: forceYAxisValueDecimals

36.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all x-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all x-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all x-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
36.name: forceXAxisValueDecimals

6.category: The color Object and The colorRange Object

0.description: The starting value for the trendline. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trendline from value 102 to 109, the `startValue` would be 102.
0.name: startValue

1.description: The ending y-axis value for the trendline. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trendline from value 102 to 109, the `endValue` would be 109. If you do not specify a value for `endValue`, it would automatically assume the same value as `startValue`.
1.name: endValue

2.description: If you want to display a string caption for the trend line by its side, you can use this attribute. Example:` displayValue='Last Month High'`. When you don't supply this attribute, it automatically takes the value of `startValue`.
2.name: displayValue

3.description: Color of the trend line and its associated text
3.name: color

4.description: Whether the trend will be displayed as a line or a zone (fill-colored rectangle).
4.name: isTrendZone

5.description: Whether the trend line/zone would be displayed over data plots or behind them.
5.name: showOnTop

6.description: If you have opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define the thickness of trend line.
6.name: thickness

7.description: Alpha of the trend line.
7.name: alpha

8.description: If you have opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define whether the trend line would appear as dashed.
8.name: dashed

9.description: If you have opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash.
9.name: dashLen

10.description: If you have opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash gap.
10.name: dashGap

23.description: This configuration determines whether the numbers belonging to volume chart will be formatted using commas, e.g., 40,000 if 'vFormatNumber': '1'; and 40000 if 'vFormatNumber' : '0';
23.name: vFormatNumber

24.description: Configuration whether to add K (thousands) and M (millions) to a number belonging to volume chart after truncating and rounding it - e.g., if `vFormatNumberScale` is set to 1, 10434 would become 1.04K (with `vDecimals` set to 2 places). Same with numbers in millions - an M will be added at the end.
24.name: vFormatNumberScale

25.name: vDefaultNumberScale

26.name: vNumberScaleUnit

27.description: Range of the various blocks that constitute the scale for volume chart.
27.name: vNumberScaleValue

29.name: vMaxScaleRecursion

22.description: If you've too many items on the legend, a scroll bar shows up on the same. This attribute lets you configure the background color of the scroll bar.
22.name: legendScrollBgColor

23.description: You can reverse the ordering of datasets in the legend by setting this attribute to 1.
23.name: reverseLegend

24.description: This attribute lets you interact with the legend in your chart. When you click a legend key, the dataplots associated with that series are eliminated from the chart. Re-clicking the key causes the dataplots to reappear.
24.name: interactiveLegend

25.description: If your chart contains multiple series, the legend is displayed as a grid comprising of multiple legend keys. With the help of this attribute you can specify the number of columns that are to be displayed in the legend.
25.name: legendNumColumns

26.description: Whether to minimize legend item text wrapping.
26.name: minimiseWrappingInLegend

27.description:

30.name: legendIconAlpha

31.name: legendIconBgAlpha

33.name: legendIconBorderThickness

34.description:

 __Default Value__ : 1
23.name: visible

24.description: This configuration determines whether the numbers belonging to secondary axis will be formatted using commas, e.g., 40,000 if 'sFormatNumber': '1'; and 40000 if 'sFormatNumber': '0';
24.name: sFormatNumber

25.description: Configuration whether to add K (thousands) and M (millions) to a number belonging to secondary axis after truncating and rounding it - e.g., if `sFormatNumberScale` is set to 1, 10434 will become 1.04K (with decimalPrecision set to 2 places). Same with numbers in millions - an M will be added at the end.
25.name: sFormatNumberScale

26.description: The default unit of the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
26.name: sDefaultNumberScale

27.description: Unit of each block of the scale of secondary y-axis.
27.name: sNumberScaleUnit

28.description: Range of the various blocks that constitute the scale for secondary y-axis.
28.name: sNumberScaleValue

29.description:
If a data value, to be plotted on the secondary y-axis, is less than the lowest given number is the number scale, this attribute forces the lower value of the  `sNumberScaleUnit` to be applied to that data value.  This attribute works only when `“sFormatNumberScale”: “1”` and the `sDefaultNumberScale` attribute is not defined. 

For example, if `“sNumberScaleUnit”: “K, M”`, `“sNumberScaleValue”: “1000, 1000”`, and `“sForceNumberScale”: “1”`, a data value of __400__ will be rendered as __0.40K__.
29.name: sForceNumberScale

30.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
30.name: sNumberPrefix

31.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
31.name: sNumberSuffix

32.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers belonging to secondary axis will be rounded to.
32.name: sDecimals

33.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the secondary div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
33.name: sYAxisValueDecimals

0.description: This attribute determines the transparency of a data item. The range for this attribute is 0 to 100. 0 means complete transparency (the data item wont be shown on the graph) and 100 means opaque.
0.name: alpha

1.description: If you want to set border alpha of individual pie/doughnut data items, you can specify using this attribute.
1.name: borderAlpha

2.description: If you want to set border color of individual pie/doughnut data items, you can specify using this attribute.
2.name: borderColor

3.description: If you want to define your own colors for the data items on chart, use this attribute to specify color for the data item.
3.name: color

4.description: Whether the border of this data item should appear as dashed. This is particularly useful when you want to highlight a data (such as forecast or trend etc.).
4.name: dashed

5.description: If instead of the numerical value of this data, you wish to display a custom string value, you can specify the same here. Examples are annotation for a data item etc.
5.name: displayValue

6.description: This attribute determines whether a pie slice appears as a part of the total chart or is sliced out as an individual item.
6.name: isSliced

7.description: This attribute determines the label for the data item. The label appears on the x-axis of chart.
7.name: label

8.description: You can define links for individual data items. That enables the end user to click on data items (columns, lines, bars etc.) and drill down to other pages. To define the link for data items, use the link attribute. You can define links that open in same window, new window, pop-up window or frames. Please see "Drill Down Charts > FusionCharts Link format" for more information. Also, you'll need to URL Encode all the special characters (like ? and &) present in the link.
8.name: link

9.description: You can individually opt to show/hide labels of individual data items using this attribute.
9.name: showLabel

10.description: You can individually opt to show/hide values of individual data items using this attribute.
10.name: showValue

11.description: By default, FusionCharts XT shows the data item name and value as tool tip text for that data item. But, if you want to display more information for the data item as tool tip, you can use this attribute to specify the same.
11.name: toolText

12.description: Numerical value for the data item. This value will be plotted on the chart.
12.name: value

13.description: Sets the x-axis label font family for the text.
13.name: labelFont

14.description: Sets the x-axis label font color.
14.name: labelFontColor

15.description: Specifies the x-axis label font size.
15.name: labelFontSize

16.description: Flag indicating whether x-axis label font should be bold or not.
16.name: labelFontBold

17.description: Flag indicating whether x-axis label font should be italicized or not.
17.name: labelFontItalic

18.description: Sets the background color for x-axis label text.
18.name: labelBgColor

19.description: Sets the color of the border around the x-axis label text.
19.name: labelBorderColor

20.description: Sets the x-axis label alpha for both font and background.
20.name: labelAlpha

21.description: Sets the x-axis label background alpha.
21.name: labelBgAlpha

22.description: Sets the x-axis label border alpha.
22.name: labelBorderAlpha

23.description: Sets the x-axis label border padding.
23.name: labelBorderPadding

24.description: Sets the x-axis label border radius.
24.name: labelBorderRadius

25.description: Sets the x-axis label border thickness.
25.name: labelBorderThickness

26.description: Whether the x-axis label border should be rendered using dashed lines?
26.name: labelBorderDashed

27.description: Sets the length of each dash line.
27.name: labelBorderDashLen

28.description: Sets the gap between two consecutive dashed lines.
28.name: labelBorderDashGap

29.description: Sets the link for each individual x-axis label.
29.name: labelLink

0.description: The starting value for the trend line. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trend line from value 102 to 109, the `startValue` would be 102.
0.name: startValue

1.description: The ending y-axis value for the trend line. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trend line from value 102 to 109, the `endValue` would be 109. If you do not specify a value for `endValue`, it would automatically assume the same value as `startValue`.
1.name: endValue

2.description: If you want to display a string caption for the trend line by its side, you can use this attribute. Example:` displayValue='Last Month High'`. When you do not supply this attribute, it automatically takes the value of `startValue`.
2.name: displayValue

3.description: Color of the trend line and its associated text
3.name: color

4.description: Whether the trend will be displayed as a line or a zone (fill-colored rectangle).
4.name: isTrendZone

5.description: If you have opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define the thickness of trend line.
5.name: thickness

6.description: Alpha of the trend line.
6.name: alpha

7.description: If you have opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define whether the trend line would appear as dashed.
7.name: dashed

8.description: If you have opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash.
8.name: dashLen

9.description: If you have opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash gap.
9.name: dashGap

10.description: Custom tool-text for this trend line or zone.
10.name: toolText

11.description: Sets the thickness for the border around the trend-line display value.
11.name: trendValueBorderThickness

12.description:
Sets whether the border around the trend-line display value will be drawn as a dashed line. 

Default value: 0 (drawn as a straight line)
12.name: trendValueBorderDashed

13.description: Sets the length of each dash, if the border around the trend-line display value is drawn as a dashed line.

0.description: The starting value for the trend line. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trend line from value 102 to 109, the `startValue` would be 102.
0.name: startValue

1.description: The ending y-axis value for the trend line. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trend line from value 102 to 109, the `endValue` would be 109. If you do not specify a value for `endValue`, it would automatically assume the same value as `startValue`.
1.name: endValue

2.description: If you want to display a string caption for the trend line by its side, you can use this attribute. Example: `displayValue='Last Month High'`. When you do not supply this attribute, it automatically takes the value of `startValue`.
2.name: displayValue

3.description: Color of the trend line and its associated text
3.name: color

4.description: Whether the trend will be displayed as a line or a zone (fill-colored rectangle).
4.name: isTrendZone

5.description: If you have opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define the thickness of trend line.
5.name: thickness

6.description: Alpha of the trend line.
6.name: alpha

7.description: If you have opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define Whether the trend line would appear as dashed.
7.name: dashed

8.description: If you have opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash.
8.name: dashLen

34.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, PowerCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the decimal separator.
34.name: inDecimalSeparator

35.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, PowerCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the thousand separator.
35.name: inThousandSeparator

36.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers on the chart will be rounded to.
36.name: decimals

37.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all the numbers, set this attribute to 1.
37.name: forceDecimals

38.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
38.name: forceYAxisValueDecimals

39.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all x-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all x-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all x-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
39.name: forceXAxisValueDecimals

40.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
40.name: yAxisValueDecimals

41.description: If you've opted not to adjust vertical div lines, you can specify the decimal precision of the div line values using this attribute.
41.name: xAxisValueDecimals

54.description: Lets you set the hover band color for all `processes` objects. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.

55.description: Lets you set the transparency of the hover band for all `processes` objects. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
55.name: processHoverBandAlpha

56.description: Whether to show the hover bands for the `processes` object of the Gantt pane on mouse hover. The value of this attribute overrides the value `showHoverEffect` attribute. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
56.name: showGanttPaneHorizontalHoverBand

57.description: Whether to display the mouse hover effect on connector lines. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
57.name: showConnectorHoverEffect

58.description: Lets you set the hover color of the connector lines. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
58.name: connectorHoverColor

59.description: Lets you set the transparency of the hover color of the connector lines. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.

60.description: Lets you set the thickness of the connector lines after the mouse cursor hover. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.

61.description: Whether to use the mouse hover effect of task bars. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.

62.description: Lets you set the color of task fill on mouse hover. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
62.name: taskHoverFillColor

63.name: taskHoverFillAlpha

64.description: Lets you set the hover color of the task bar slack. This attribute is not applicable when `showSlackAsFill` is set to 0. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
64.name: slackHoverFillColor

65.description: Lets you set the transparency of the hover color of the task bar slack fill. This attribute is not applicable when `showSlackAsFill` is set to 0. This feature is supported by JavaScript Gantt chart only.
65.name: slackHoverFillAlpha

0.description: Hex code of the color range using which it will be filled.
0.name: code

1.description: This attribute determines the label for each numeric range. The label appears either on the gradient scale or on icon legends depending on the legend type used.
1.name: label

2.description: Specifies the upper limits of each numeric range. This attribute is mandatory in each `color` object for both gradient and icon legend.
2.name: maxValue

3.description: Specifies the lower limits of each numeric range. This attribute is mandatory in each `color` object when icon legend is used.
3.name: minValue

4.description: Sets the minimum value or the lower limit of the numeric range and the gradient scale.
4.name: minValue

5.description: Specifies the label for the lower limit of the gradient scale.
5.name: startLabel

6.description: This attribute allows you to display a label on the top-right corner of a data plot.
6.name: trLabel
6.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

7.description: This attribute allows you to display a label on the bottom-left corner of a data plot.
7.name: blLabel
7.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

8.description: This attribute allows you to display a label on the bottom-left corner of a data plot.
8.name: brLabel
8.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

9.description: In Heat map chart, if you wish to highlight a particular cell, you can specify it's color at "set" level using this attribute.
9.name: color
9.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

10.description: You can define links for individual data items. That enables the end user to click on data items (columns, lines, bars etc.) and drill down to other pages. To define the link for data items, use the link attribute. You can define links that open in same window, new window, pop-up window or frames. Please see "Drill Down Charts > FusionCharts Link format" for more information. Also, you need to Url Encode all the special characters (like ? and &) present in the link.
10.name: link
10.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

11.description: By default, Heat map chart shows the value or display value as tool tip text for that data item. It also includes all the values provided through `trLabel`, `tlLabel`, `brlabel `and `bllabel` attributes along with the values of `trType`,` tlType`,` brType `and` blType `attributes. Click here to see how a default tool tip looks like when all the above attributes are provided. But, if you want to display more information or if you want to provide customized information for the data item as tool tip, you can use this attribute to specify the same.
11.name: toolText
11.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

12.description: You can individually opt to show or hide values of individual data items using this attribute. This value over-rides the data-set level value.
12.name: showValue
12.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

13.description: For Multi-series charts, you can define the alpha of data-sets at dataset level. However, if you wish to highlight a particular data element, you can specify its alpha at "set" level using this attribute.
13.name: alpha
13.category: The dataset Object and the data Object

14.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, the chart accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the decimal separator.
14.name: inDecimalSeparator

15.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, the chart accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the thousand separator.
15.name: inThousandSeparator

16.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers on the chart would be rounded to.
16.name: decimals

17.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all the numbers, set this attribute to 1.
17.name: forceDecimals

18.description: Border thickness for the legend.
18.name: legendBorderThickness

19.description: Border alpha for the legend.
19.name: legendBorderAlpha

20.description: Whether to show a shadow for legend.
20.name: legendShadow

21.description: The legend can be made drag-able by setting this attribute to 1. End viewers of the chart can drag the legend around on the chart.
21.name: legendAllowDrag

22.description: If you have too many items on the legend, a scroll bar shows up on the same. This attribute lets you configure the background color of the scroll bar.

23.description: You can reverse the order of datasets in the legend by setting this attribute to 1.
23.name: reverseLegend

24.description: This attribute lets you interact with the legend in your chart. When you click a legend key, the dataplots associated with that series are eliminated from the chart. Re-clicking the key causes the dataplots to reappear.
24.name: interactiveLegend

25.description: If your chart contains multiple series, the legend is displayed as a grid comprising of multiple legend keys. With the help of this attribute you can specify the number of columns that are to be displayed in the legend.
25.name: legendNumColumns

26.description: Whether to minimize legend item text wrapping.
26.name: minimiseWrappingInLegend

31.name: legendPointerBorderAlpha

Specifies whether drawing a custom legend icon will be enabled. All legend icon customization attributes will work only if this feature is enabled. 

Default value: 0 (disabled)
37.name: drawCustomLegendIcon

38.description:
Sets the border color for the legend icon. 

Default value: Data plot border color
38.name: legendIconBorderColor

39.description:
Sets the background color for the legend icon. 

Default value: Data plot fill color
39.name: legendIconBgColor

40.description:
Sets the legend icon transparency. 

Default value: 100
40.name: legendIconAlpha

41.description:
Sets the legend icon background transparency. 

Default value: 100
41.name: legendIconBgAlpha

Sets the number of sides for the legend icon. 

Default value: 4
42.name: legendIconSides

Sets the thickness of the legend icon border. 

Default value: 1
43.name: legendIconBorderThickness

44.description:
Sets the starting angle of for drawing the legend icon. 

Default value: 45
44.name: legendIconStartAngle

45.description: This attribute if set to `0`, the legend box will be center aligned with respect to the entire width of the chart only if the total width of the legend box is more than the canvas width. By default, the legend box is center aligned with respect to the canvas width and it remains the same if the width of the legend box is less than the canvas width.

17.description: If you've opted to show a particular data value on the chart, this attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of individual data values with respect to dataplots. By default, this attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of a data value is determined automatically based on the position of its plot point. In ABOVE mode, a data value is displayed above the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas while in BELOW mode, a data value is displayed below the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas.
17.name: valuePosition

0.description: Alpha of the trend line.

11.name: showOnTop

0.description: Numerical value for the data item. This value would be plotted on the chart.
0.name: value

1.description: For Multi-series and Combination charts, you can define the color of data-sets at dataset level. However, if you wish to highlight a particular data element, you can specify its color at "set" level using this attribute.
1.name: color

2.description: If instead of the numerical value of this data, you wish to display a custom string value, you can specify the same here. Examples are annotation for a data item etc.
2.name: displayValue

3.description: You can define links for individual data items. That enables the end user to click on data items (columns, lines, bars etc.) and drill down to other pages. To define the link for data items, use the link attribute. You can define links that open in same window, new window, pop-up window or frames. Please see Advanced Charting > Drill Down Charts for more information. Also, you need to URL Encode all the special characters (like ? and &) present in the link.
3.name: link

4.description: By default, PowerCharts XT shows the series name, category name, and value as tool tip text for that data item. But, if you want to display more information for the data item as tool tip, you can use this attribute to specify the same.
4.name: toolText

5.description: You can individually opt to show or hide values of individual data items using this attribute. This value over-rides the data-set level value.
5.name: showValue

6.description: If you have opted to show a particular data value on the chart, this attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of individual data values with respect to dataplots. By default, this attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of a data value is determined automatically based on the position of its plot point. In ABOVE mode, a data value is displayed above the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas while in BELOW mode, a data value is displayed below the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas.
6.name: valuePosition

7.description: Whether the border of this data item should appear as dashed. This is particularly useful when you want to highlight a data (such as forecast or trend etc.). This value over-rides the data-set level value.
7.name: dashed

8.description: For Multi-series and Combination charts, you can define the alpha of data-sets at dataset level. However, if you wish to highlight a particular data element, you can specify its alpha at "set" level using this attribute.
8.name: alpha

9.description: Lets you specify "set" specific alpha of the anchor background.
9.name: anchorBgAlpha

10.description: Lets you specify "set" specific background color of the anchor.
10.name: anchorBgColor

11.description: Lets you specify "set" specific alpha of the anchor.
11.name: anchorAlpha

12.description: Lets you specify "set" specific sides of the anchor.
12.name: anchorSides

13.description: Lets you specify "set" specific radius (in pixels) of the anchor.
13.name: anchorRadius

14.description: Lets you specify "set" specific border color of the anchor.
14.name: anchorBorderColor

15.description: Lets you specify "set" specific border thickness of the anchor.
15.name: anchorBorderThickness

16.description: Helps you set the alpha of entire anchors of the particular data-set. If you need to hide the anchors for the data-set but still enable tool tips, set this as 0.
16.name: anchorAlpha

17.description: Helps you set the alpha of anchor background of the particular data-set.
17.name: anchorBgAlpha

18.description: If the lines are to be shown as dash, this attribute defines the length of dash.
18.name: lineDashLen

19.description: Whether the data-sets under this axis would appear as dashed.
19.name: lineDashed

20.description: Thickness of the lines for the data-sets under this axis.
20.name: lineThickness

21.description: How many recursions to complete during recursive scaling? -1 completes the entire set of recursion.
21.name: maxScaleRecursion

22.description: This attribute helps you explicitly set the upper limit of the axis. If you do not specify this value, it is automatically calculated by the chart based on the data provided by you.
22.name: maxValue

23.description: This attribute helps you explicitly set the lower limit of the axis. If you do not specify this value, it is automatically calculated by the chart based on the data provided by you.
23.name: minValue

24.description: Number of horizontal axis division lines that you want for this axis.
24.name: numDivLines

25.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers visible on the chart for this axis. For example, to represent all dollars figure on the chart, you could specify this attribute to $ to show like $40000, $50000.
25.name: numberPrefix

26.description: Unit of each block of the scale.
26.name: numberScaleUnit

27.description: Range of the various blocks that constitute the scale.
27.name: numberScaleValue

28.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers visible on the chart for this axis. For example, to represent all figures quantified as per annum on the chart, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a.
28.name: numberSuffix

29.description: Whether recursive scaling should be applied.

15.description: If you've opted to show a particular data value on the chart, this attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of individual data values with respect to dataplots. By default, this attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of a data value is determined automatically based on the position of its plot point. In ABOVE mode, a data value is displayed above the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas while in BELOW mode, a data value is displayed below the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas.
15.name: valuePosition

16.description: Lets you specify the series name for a particular dataset. For example, if you're plotting a chart to indicate monthly sales analysis for 2005 and 2006, the `seriesName` for the first dataset will be 2005 and that of the second will be 2006. The seriesName of a dataset is shown in legend.
16.name: seriesName

17.description: Whether to show the values for this dataset.
17.name: showValues

18.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all dataplots in the dataset. The alignment is set with respect to the position of the dataplots on the chart. By default, the attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of each data value is determined automatically based on the position of each plot point. In ABOVE mode, data values are displayed above the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas. While in BELOW mode, data values are displayed below the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas. The attribute will function only if `showValue` attribute is set to 1 in this particular dataset.
18.name: valuePosition

19.description:
Sets whether a dataset will be visible on the chart, when the chart is first loaded. This attribute overrides the `initiallyHidden` attribute. 

 __Default Value__ : 1
19.name: visible

20.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all the numbers, set this attribute to 1.
20.name: forceDecimals

21.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
21.name: forceYAxisValueDecimals

22.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all secondary y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all secondary y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all secondary y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
22.name: forceSYAxisValueDecimals

23.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
23.name: yAxisValueDecimals

24.description: This configuration determines whether the numbers belonging to secondary axis will be formatted using commas, e.g., 40,000 if 'sFormatNumber': '1'; and 40000 if 'sFormatNumber': '0';
24.name: sFormatNumber

25.description: Configuration whether to add K (thousands) and M (millions) to a number belonging to secondary axis after truncating and rounding it - e.g., if `sFormatNumberScale` is set to 1, 10434 will become 1.04K (with decimalPrecision set to 2 places). Same with numbers in millions - an M will be added at the end.
25.name: sFormatNumberScale

26.description: The default unit of the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
26.name: sDefaultNumberScale

27.description: Unit of each block of the scale of secondary y-axis.
27.name: sNumberScaleUnit

28.description: Range of the various blocks that constitute the scale for secondary y-axis.
28.name: sNumberScaleValue

29.description:
If a data value, to be plotted on the secondary y-axis, is less than the lowest given number is the number scale, this attribute forces the lower value of the  `sNumberScaleUnit` to be applied to that data value.  This attribute works only when `“sFormatNumberScale”: “1”` and the `sDefaultNumberScale` attribute is not defined. 

For example, if `“sNumberScaleUnit”: “K, M”`, `“sNumberScaleValue”: “1000, 1000”`, and `“sForceNumberScale”: “1”`, a data value of __400__ will be rendered as __0.40K__.
29.name: sForceNumberScale

30.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
30.name: sNumberPrefix

31.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
31.name: sNumberSuffix

32.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers belonging to secondary axis will be rounded to.
32.name: sDecimals

33.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the secondary div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
33.name: sYAxisValueDecimals

15.description: If you've opted to show a particular data value on the chart, this attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of individual data values with respect to dataplots. By default, this attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of a data value is determined automatically based on the position of its plot point. In ABOVE mode, a data value is displayed above the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas while in BELOW mode, a data value is displayed below the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas.
15.name: valuePosition

16.description: Whether to show the values for this dataset.
16.name: showValues

17.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all dataplots in the dataset. The alignment is set with respect to the position of the dataplots on the chart. By default, the attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of each data value is determined automatically based on the position of each plot point. In ABOVE mode, data values are displayed above the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas. While in BELOW mode, data values are displayed below the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas. The attribute will function only if showValue attribute is set to 1 in this particular dataset.
17.name: valuePosition

17.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all dataplots in the dataset. The alignment is set with respect to the position of the dataplots on the chart. By default, the attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of each data value is determined automatically based on the position of each plot point. In ABOVE mode, data values are displayed above the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas. While in BELOW mode, data values are displayed below the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas. The attribute will function only if showValue attribute is set to 1 in this particular data-set.
17.name: valuePosition

1.description: Sets the font size for the trend-line display value.
1.name: trendValueFontSize

2.description:
Sets whether the trend-line display value will be bold formatted. 

Default value: 0 (not bold formatted)
2.name: trendValueFontBold

3.description:
Sets whether the trend-line display value will be italicized. 

Default value: 0 (not italicized)
3.name: trendValueFontItalic

4.description: Sets the background color for the trend-line display value.
4.name: trendValueBgColor

5.description: Sets the border color for the trend-line display value.
5.name: trendValueBorderColor

6.description:
Sets the transparency for the trend-line display value. 

Default value: 100
6.name: trendValueAlpha

7.description:
Sets the transparency for the background of the trend-line display value. 

Default value: 100
7.name: trendValueBgAlpha

8.description:
Sets the transparency for the border around the trend-line display value. 

Default value: 100
8.name: trendValueBorderAlpha

9.description: Sets padding for the border around the trend-line display value.
9.name: trendValueBorderPadding

10.description: Sets the radius for the border around the trend-line display value.
10.name: trendValueBorderRadius

11.description: Sets the thickness for the border around the trend-line display value.
11.name: trendValueBorderThickness

12.description:
Sets whether the border around the trend-line display value will be drawn as a dashed line. 

Default value: 0 (drawn as a straight line)
12.name: trendValueBorderDashed

13.description: Sets the length of each dash, if the border around the trend-line display value is drawn as a dashed line.
13.name: trendValueBorderDashLen

14.description: Sets the gap between each dash, if the border around the trend-line display value is drawn as a dashed line.
14.name: trendValueBorderDashGap

15.description: If you've opted to show a particular data value on the line, this attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of individual data values with respect to a line. By default, this attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of a data value is determined automatically based on the position of its plot point. In ABOVE mode, a data value is displayed above the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas while in BELOW mode, a data value is displayed below the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas.
15.name: valuePosition
15.category: The data Object (child of the lineset Object)

16.description: Whether to show the values for this line-set.
16.name: showValues

17.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all lines in the line-set.
17.name: valuePosition

18.description: Sets the gap between two consecutive dashed lines.
18.name: borderDashGap

19.description: Sets the link for each individual x-axis label.
19.name: link

20.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all the numbers, set this attribute to 1.
20.name: forceDecimals

21.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
21.name: forceYAxisValueDecimals

22.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all secondary y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all secondary y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all secondary y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
22.name: forceSYAxisValueDecimals

23.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
23.name: yAxisValueDecimals

24.description: This configuration determines whether the numbers belonging to secondary axis will be formatted using commas, e.g., 40,000 if 'sFormatNumber': '1'; and 40000 if 'sFormatNumber': '0';
24.name: sFormatNumber

25.description: Configuration whether to add K (thousands) and M (millions) to a number belonging to secondary axis after truncating and rounding it - e.g., if `sFormatNumberScale` is set to 1, 10434 will become 1.04K (with decimalPrecision set to 2 places). Same with numbers in millions - an M will be added at the end.
25.name: sFormatNumberScale

26.description: The default unit of the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
26.name: sDefaultNumberScale

27.description: Unit of each block of the scale of secondary y-axis.
27.name: sNumberScaleUnit

28.description: Range of the various blocks that constitute the scale for secondary y-axis.
28.name: sNumberScaleValue

29.description:
If a data value, to be plotted on the secondary y-axis, is less than the lowest given number is the number scale, this attribute forces the lower value of the  `sNumberScaleUnit` to be applied to that data value.  This attribute works only when `“sFormatNumberScale”: “1”` and the `sDefaultNumberScale` attribute is not defined. 

For example, if `“sNumberScaleUnit”: “K, M”`, `“sNumberScaleValue”: “1000, 1000”`, and `“sForceNumberScale”: “1”`, a data value of __400__ will be rendered as __0.40K__.
29.name: sForceNumberScale

30.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
30.name: sNumberPrefix

31.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
31.name: sNumberSuffix

32.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers belonging to secondary axis will be rounded to.
32.name: sDecimals

33.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the secondary div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
33.name: sYAxisValueDecimals

15.description: If you have opted to show a particular data value on the chart, this attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of individual data values with respect to dataplots. By default, this attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of a data value is determined automatically based on the position of its plot point. In ABOVE mode, a data value is displayed above the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas while in BELOW mode, a data value is displayed below the plot point unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas.
15.name: valuePosition

16.description: Whether to show the values for this data-set.
16.name: showValues

17.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all dataplots in the dataset. The alignment is set with respect to the position of the dataplots on the chart. By default, the attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of each data value is determined automatically based on the position of each plot point. In ABOVE mode, data values are displayed above the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas. While in BELOW mode, data values are displayed below the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas. The attribute will function only if showValue attribute is set to 1 in this particular data-set.
17.name: valuePosition

18.description: Sets the gap between two consecutive dashed lines.
18.name: borderDashGap

21.description: The legend can be made drag-able by setting this attribute to 1. End viewers of the chart can drag the legend around on the chart.

22.description: If you have too many items on the legend, a scroll bar shows up on the same. This attribute lets you configure the background color of the scroll bar.
22.name: legendScrollBgColor

23.description: You can reverse the order of datasets in the legend by setting this attribute to 1.
23.name: reverseLegend

24.description: This attribute lets you interact with the legend in your chart. When you click a legend key, the dataplots associated with that series are eliminated from the chart. Re-clicking the key causes the dataplots to reappear.
24.name: interactiveLegend

25.description: If your chart contains multiple series, the legend is displayed as a grid comprising of multiple legend keys. With the help of this attribute you can specify the number of columns that are to be displayed in the legend.
25.name: legendNumColumn

26.description: Whether to minimize legend item text wrapping.
26.name: minimiseWrappingInLegend

27.description:

Default value: 0 (disabled)
27.name: drawCustomLegendIcon

Default value: Data plot border color

Default value: 100
30.name: legendIconAlpha

32.description:
Sets the number of sides for the legend icon. 

Default value: 4
32.name: legendIconSides

Sets the thickness of the legend icon border.

34.description:
Sets the starting angle of for drawing the legend icon.

0.description: Alpha for the pie.
0.name: alpha

1.description: Color for the pie
1.name: color

2.description: Display value for the pie.
2.name: label

3.description: Link for the pie.
3.name: link

4.description: The tooltip defined in the `category` object appears only when the mouse cursor is hovered over the individual slices. However, this will not appear when the cursor is moved over the data labels (except for a situation when long labels are automatically truncated with ellipses. In this situation, if the mouse cursor is hovered over a truncated label, the tooltip will appear with the full label). In case you want to set a short label and show the full label in tooltip, define the full label using this attribute within the `category` object. The tooltip with the full label will appear only when the mouse is hovered on the particular slice.
4.name: toolText

5.description: If you do not want a symmetrical distribution for all the pies, you can allot numeric values to individual pies. This can be done using the value attribute of each category. You will need to define the value for all the categories (pies) then. The sweep angle of the pie would depend on its value. If you just want a symmetrical multi-level pie chart, you can ignore the value.
5.name: value

6.description: The color which should be used as fill during hover.
6.name: hoverFillColor

7.description: Whether to show shadow for tool-tips on the chart.
7.name: showToolTipShadow

8.description: This attribute works on text of the tooltip. It is used to specify the text, i.e. you can use it to give a specific constant string for every tooltip. You can also use variable values from the data level by putting a "$" sign infront of it, eg $name, and you'll get the value of the name in the tooltip according to the pie.
8.name: plottooltext

9.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers visible on the graph. For example, to represent all dollars figure on the chart, you could specify this attribute to $ to show like $40000, $50000.
9.name: numberPrefix

10.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the graph. For example, to represent all figures quantified as per annum on the chart, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a.
10.name: numberSuffix

11.description: This attribute helps you specify the character to be used as the decimal separator in a number.
11.name: decimalSeparator

12.description: This attribute helps you specify the character to be used as the thousands separator in a number.
12.name: thousandSeparator

13.description: This option helps you specify the position of the thousand separator.
13.name: thousandSeparatorPosition

14.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, FusionCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the decimal separator.
14.name: inDecimalSeparator

15.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, FusionCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the thousand separator.
15.name: inThousandSeparator

16.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers on the chart will be rounded to.
16.name: decimals

17.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, if you set decimals as 2 and a number is 23.4. If forceDecimals is set to 1, FusionCharts XT will convert the number to 23.40 (note the extra 0 at the end).
17.name: forceDecimals

18.description: If you want to link the logo to an external URL, specify the link in this attribute. The link can be in FusionCharts Link Format, allowing you to link to new windows, pop-ups, frames etc.
18.name: logoLink

0.description: This attribute determines the transparency of a data item. The range for this attribute is 0 to 100. 0 means complete transparency (the data item wont be shown on the graph) and 100 means opaque.
0.name: alpha

1.description: If you want to set border alpha of individual pie/doughnut data items, you can specify using this attribute.
1.name: borderAlpha

2.description: If you want to set border color of individual pie/doughnut data items, you can specify using this attribute.
2.name: borderColor

3.description: If you want to define your own colors for the data items on chart, use this attribute to specify color for the data item.
3.name: color

4.description: Whether the border of this data item should appear as dashed. This is particularly useful when you want to highlight a data (such as forecast or trend etc.).
4.name: dashed

5.description: If instead of the numerical value of this data, you wish to display a custom string value, you can specify the same here. Examples are annotation for a data item etc.
5.name: displayValue

6.description: This attribute determines whether a pie slice appears as a part of the total chart or is sliced out as an individual item.
6.name: isSliced

7.description: This attribute determines the label for the data item. The label appears on the x-axis of chart.
7.name: label

8.description: You can define links for individual data items. That enables the end user to click on data items (columns, lines, bars etc.) and drill down to other pages. To define the link for data items, use the link attribute. You can define links that open in same window, new window, pop-up window or frames. Please see "Drill Down Charts > FusionCharts Link format" for more information. Also, you'll need to URL Encode all the special characters (like ? and &) present in the link.
8.name: link

9.description: You can individually opt to show/hide labels of individual data items using this attribute.
9.name: showLabel

10.description: You can individually opt to show/hide values of individual data items using this attribute.
10.name: showValue

11.description: By default, FusionCharts XT shows the data item name and value as tool tip text for that data item. But, if you want to display more information for the data item as tool tip, you can use this attribute to specify the same.
11.name: toolText

12.description: Numerical value for the data item. This value will be plotted on the chart.
12.name: value

0.description: Numerical value for the data item. This value would be plotted on the chart.

1.description: For Multi-series charts, you can define the color of data-sets at dataset level. However, if you wish to highlight a particular data element, you can specify its color at "set" level using this attribute.
1.name: color

2.description: If instead of the numerical value of this data, you wish to display a custom string value, you can specify the same here. Examples are annotation for a data item etc.

3.description: You can define links for individual data items. That enables the end user to click on data items (columns, lines, bars etc.) and drill down to other pages. To define the link for data items, use the link attribute. You can define links that open in same window, new window, pop-up window or frames. Please see Advanced Charting > Drill Down Charts for more information. Also, you'll need to URL Encode all the special characters (like ? and &) present in the link.

5.name: showValue

18.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all the dataplots in the dataset. The alignment is set with respect to the position of the dataplots on the chart. By default, the attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of each data value is determined automatically based on the position of each plot point. In ABOVE mode, data values are displayed above the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas. While in BELOW mode, data values are displayed below the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas. The attribute will function only if `showValue` attribute is set to 1 in this particular dataset.
18.name: valuePosition

9.name: trendValueBorderPadding

11.name: trendValueBorderThickness

Sets whether the border around the trend-line display value will be drawn as a dashed line. 

Default value: 0 (drawn as a straight line)

13.name: trendValueBorderDashLen

14.name: trendValueBorderDashGap

15.description: Thickness of the lines for the particular dataset.
15.name: lineThickness

16.description: This attribute allows you to set the parent axis of the dataset - P (primary) or S (secondary). Primary datasets are drawn against the left y-axis and the secondary against the right-axis.
16.name: parentYAxis

17.description: Lets you specify the series name for a particular dataset. For example, if you're plotting a chart to indicate monthly sales analysis for 2005 and 2006, the `seriesName` for the first dataset will be 2005 and that of the second will be 2006. The `seriesName` of a dataset is shown in legend.
17.name: seriesName

18.description: Whether to show the values for this dataset?
18.name: showValues

19.description: This attribute lets you adjust the vertical alignment of data values for all the dataplots in the dataset. The alignment is set with respect to the position of the dataplots on the chart. By default, the attribute is set to AUTO mode in which the alignment of each data value is determined automatically based on the position of each plot point. In ABOVE mode, data values are displayed above the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the upper edge of the canvas. While in BELOW mode, data values are displayed below the plot points unless a plot point is too close to the lower edge of the canvas. The attribute will function only if showValue attribute is set to 1 in this particular dataset.
19.name: valuePosition

20.description: Whether to show a shadow for legend?
20.name: legendShadow

21.description: The legend can be made drag-able by setting this attribute to 1. End viewers of the chart can drag the legend around on the chart.
21.name: legendAllowDrag

22.description: If you've too many items on the legend, a scroll bar shows up on the same. This attribute lets you configure the background color of the scroll bar.
22.name: legendScrollBgColor

23.description: You can reverse the ordering of datasets in the legend by setting this attribute to 1.
23.name: reverseLegend

24.description: Scaling of legend icon is possible starting FusionWidgets XT. This attribute lets you control the size of legend icon.
24.name: legendIconScale

25.description: If your chart contains multiple series, the legend is displayed as a grid comprising of multiple legend keys. With the help of this attribute you can specify the number of columns that are to be displayed in the legend.
25.name: legendNumColumns

26.description: Whether to minimize legend item text wrapping.
26.name: minimiseWrappingInLegend

27.description:
Specifies whether drawing a custom legend icon will be enabled. All legend icon customization attributes will work only if this feature is enabled. 

Default value: 0 (disabled)
27.name: drawCustomLegendIcon

0.description: The starting value for the trendline. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trendline from value 102 to 109, the `startValue` will be 102.
0.name: startValue

1.description: The ending y-axis value for the trendline. Say, if you want to plot a slanted trendline from value 102 to 109, the `endValue` will be 109. If you do not specify a value for `endValue`, it will automatically assume the same value as `startValue`.
1.name: endValue

2.description: If you want to display a string caption for the trend line by its side, you can use this attribute. Example: `displayValue='Last Month High'`. When you don't supply this attribute, it automatically takes the value of `startValue`.
2.name: displayValue

3.description: Color of the trend line and its associated text
3.name: color

4.description: Whether the trend will be displayed as a line or a zone (fill-colored rectangle).
4.name: isTrendZone

5.description: If you've opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define the thickness of trend line.
5.name: thickness

6.description: Alpha of the trend line.
6.name: alpha

7.description: If you've opted to show the trend as a line, this attribute lets you define whether the trend line will appear as dashed.
7.name: dashed

8.description: If you've opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash.
8.name: dashLen

9.description: If you've opted to show trend line as dash, this attribute lets you control the length of each dash gap.
9.name: dashGap

10.description: Custom tool-text for this trendline/zone.
10.name: toolText

11.description: Sets the thickness for the border around the trend-line display value.
11.name: trendValueBorderThickness

12.description:
Sets whether the border around the trend-line display value will be drawn as a dashed line. 

Default value: 0 (drawn as a straight line)
12.name: trendValueBorderDashed

13.description: Sets the length of each dash, if the border around the trend-line display value is drawn as a dashed line.
13.name: trendValueBorderDashLen

14.description: Sets the gap between each dash, if the border around the trend-line display value is drawn as a dashed line.
14.name: trendValueBorderDashGap

15.description: Alpha of the lines connecting the scatter points.
15.name: lineAlpha

16.description: Thickness of the lines for the particular dataset.
16.name: lineThickness

17.description: Configuration Whether to show the lines connecting the scatter points as dash.
17.name: lineDashed

18.description: If the lines are to be shown as dash for the particular dataset, this attribute defines the length of dash.
18.name: lineDashLen

19.description: Sets the gap between two consecutive dashes.
19.name: lineDashGap

20.description: This attribute when set to '1' draws a regression line for the corresponding `dataset` object in the chart.
20.name: showRegressionLine

21.description: When it is set to '1' the regression line is drawn using Y On X mode and when the attribute is set to '0' the regression line is drawn using X On Y mode. By default, this attribute is set to '1'.
21.name: showYOnX

22.description: This attribute allows you to set the color of the regression line.
22.name: regressionLineColor

23.description: This attribute allows you to set the thickness of the regression line.
23.name: regressionLineThickness

24.description: This attribute allows you to set the transparency of the regression line.
24.name: regressionLineAlpha

25.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the graph. For example, to represent all figures quantified as per annum on the chart, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a. The value of this attribute works only if `yNumberSuffix` and `xNumberSuffix` attributes are not specifically mentioned.
25.name: numberSuffix

26.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the y-axis. For example, to represent all figure quantified as per annum on the y-axis, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a. If this attribute is not specifically mentioned, the chart inherits the default value from `numberSuffix` attribute.
26.name: yNumberSuffix

27.description: Using this attribute, you could add a suffix to all the numbers visible on the x-axis. For example, to represent all figure quantified as per annum on the x-axis, you could specify this attribute to '/a' to show like 40000/a, 50000/a.If this attribute is not specifically mentioned, the chart inherits the default value from `numberSuffix` attribute.
27.name: xNumberSuffix

28.description: This attribute helps you specify the character to be used as the decimal separator in a number.
28.name: decimalSeparator

29.description: This attribute helps you specify the character to be used as the thousands separator in a number.
29.name: thousandSeparator

30.description: This option helps you specify the position of the thousand separator.
30.name: thousandSeparatorPosition

31.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, FusionCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the decimal separator.
31.name: inDecimalSeparator

32.description: In some countries, commas are used as decimal separators and dots as thousand separators. In XML, if you specify such values, it will give an error while converting to number. So, FusionCharts XT accepts the input decimal and thousand separator from user, so that it can convert it accordingly into the required format. This attribute lets you input the thousand separator.
32.name: inThousandSeparator

33.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers on the chart will be rounded to.
33.name: decimals

34.description: Whether to add 0 padding at the end of decimal numbers. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all the numbers, set this attribute to 1.
34.name: forceDecimals

35.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all y-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all y-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all y-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
35.name: forceYAxisValueDecimals

36.description: Whether to forcefully attach decimal places to all x-axis values. For example, If you limit the maximum number of decimal digits to 2, a number like 55.345 will be rounded to 55.34. This does not mean that all x-axis numbers will be displayed with a fixed number of decimal places. For instance 55 will not be displayed as 55.00 and 55.1 will not become 55.10. In order to have fixed number of decimal places attached to all x-axis numbers, set this attribute to 1.
36.name: forceXAxisValueDecimals

37.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
37.name: yAxisValueDecimals

38.description: If you've opted not to adjust vertical div lines, you can specify the decimal precision of the div line values using this attribute.
38.name: xAxisValueDecimals

24.description: This configuration determines whether the numbers belonging to secondary axis will be formatted using commas, e.g., 40,000 if 'sFormatNumber': '1'; and 40000 if 'sFormatNumber': '0';
24.name: sFormatNumber

25.description: Configuration whether to add K (thousands) and M (millions) to a number belonging to secondary axis after truncating and rounding it - e.g., if `sFormatNumberScale` is set to 1, 10434 will become 1.04K (with decimalPrecision set to 2 places). Same with numbers in millions - a M will be added at the end.
25.name: sFormatNumberScale

26.description: The default unit of the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
26.name: sDefaultNumberScale

27.description: Unit of each block of the scale of secondary y-axis.
27.name: sNumberScaleUnit

28.description: Range of the various blocks that constitute the scale for secondary y-axis.
28.name: sNumberScaleValue

29.description:
If a data value, to be plotted on the secondary y-axis, is less than the lowest given number is the number scale, this attribute forces the lower value of the  `sNumberScaleUnit` to be applied to that data value.  This attribute works only when `“sFormatNumberScale”: “1”` and the `sDefaultNumberScale` attribute is not defined. 

For example, if `“sNumberScaleUnit”: “K, M”`, `“sNumberScaleValue”: “1000, 1000”`, and `“sForceNumberScale”: “1”`, a data value of __400__ will be rendered as __0.40K__.
29.name: sForceNumberScale

30.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
30.name: sNumberPrefix

31.description: Using this attribute, you could add prefix to all the numbers belonging to secondary axis.
31.name: sNumberSuffix

32.description: Number of decimal places to which all numbers belonging to secondary axis will be rounded to.
32.name: sDecimals

33.description: If you've opted to not adjust div lines, you can specify the secondary div line values decimal precision using this attribute.
33.name: sYAxisValueDecimals
